symptoms.name: Genital/rectal/oral ulcer or papule
symptoms.pattern: Early stage, may be painless and heal quickly

symptoms.name: Proctitis
symptoms.pattern: Rectal pain, bloody or mucopurulent discharge, tenesmus, constipation.  Can be chronic and lead to strictures and fistulas.

symptoms.name: Lymphadenopathy
symptoms.pattern: Inguinal, femoral, or anorectal; may be unilateral, tender, fluctuant, suppurative, leading to bubo formation.  Can involve pelvic lymph nodes in women.

vital_signs.fever: May be present in secondary stage

physical_findings: Genital, oral, or rectal ulcerations or papules

Chlamydia serology (complement fixation.abnormal: Elevated antibody levels (not routinely used for diagnosis)

risk_factors: Men who have sex with men (MSM)
Presence of other STIs (excluding gonorrhea and syphilis)

required: Presence of proctitis (rectal bleeding, mucoid/hemopurulent discharge, abdominal/anal pain, pain with defecation, constipation, tenesmus)
Presence of inguinal, femoral, or anorectal lymphadenopathy or generalized genital lymphedema
Genital, oral, or rectal ulcerations or papules
supportive: Positive Chlamydia trachomatis NAAT for L1-L3 serovars
Elevated Chlamydia serology (complement fixation or microimmunofluorescence) titers
